attributes.description:
This section provides Machine Learning (ML) powered visualizations to help assess compliance with CCI-001050 and CCI-004618. These CCIs focus on identifying newly discovered threats and risks, and these visualizations analyze anomaly scores from an ML job that detects an unusual volume or type of new security signals.

To perform a component-level compliance assessment, utilize the global filters at the top of the Kibana dashboard. Apply filters such as 'influencers.host.name: <your_component_name>' or 'influencers.source.ip: <ip_address>' to focus on a specific system or traffic source. The ML job establishes a baseline for normal security signal generation. A high anomaly score (e.g., 75 or above) signifies a substantial deviation, such as a sudden flood of new signal types, which could indicate a coordinated attack, a new attack vector being exploited, or a widespread misconfiguration.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050, CCI-004618] ML - New Security Signals Health Status

attributes.description: This visualization displays the health status for CCI-001050 by monitoring the highest anomaly scores from its associated Machine Learning job, which detects unusual volumes of new security signals. A high anomaly score indicates a significant deviation from the baseline, suggesting that a risk review is warranted.

attributes.description:
This section provides visualizations to help you assess compliance with CCI-001050, focusing on the periodic review of risk assessment results. These visualizations leverage real-time security signal data to provide a dynamic view of your organization's risk posture.

**How to perform a component-level compliance assessment:**

1.  Utilize the global filters at the top of the Kibana dashboard to isolate specific components or assets.
2.  Apply filters like **'host.name: <your_component_name>'** or **'cloud.instance.id: <your_instance_id>'** to focus on a single system.
3.  Observe the 'Overall Risk Score' to get an immediate snapshot of open, high-priority risks for that component.
4.  Analyze the 'Risk Trend Over Time' to determine if the component's risk posture is improving or degrading.
5.  Use the 'Top Risky Hosts' visualization to identify which systems across your environment require the most immediate attention.
6.  Drill down into the 'Detailed Risk Assessment Events' table to investigate the specific alerts contributing to the risk score, understanding the 'who, what, and where' of each potential risk.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050] Review Risk Assessment Results
attributes.visState: {"title":"[CCI-001050] Review Risk Assessment Results","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"markdown":"# [CCI-001050] Review Risk Assessment Results\n\n### Review risk assessment results on an organization-defined frequency.","fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false}}

attributes.description:
**Why and when this is useful:**
This metric provides an immediate, at-a-glance summary of the current number of open security signals. It's the first place to look for a high-level snapshot of your organization's current risk posture.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this number as a baseline. A sudden increase in this count warrants immediate investigation. Compare this number over different review periods (e.g., daily or weekly) to understand the effectiveness of your risk mitigation efforts. A decreasing count is a positive sign, while a steadily increasing count indicates a worsening risk posture.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050] Overall Risk Score (Open Signals)

attributes.description:
**Why and when this is useful:**
This visualization is crucial for prioritizing your risk review efforts. It immediately shows which hosts or components are generating the most security alerts, indicating they may be misconfigured, more vulnerable, or actively targeted. Use this to focus your limited resources on the areas of highest risk.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Review the hosts in the largest segments of the pie chart first. Click on a segment to filter the entire dashboard by that specific host, allowing you to see its risk trend and detailed events. An unexpected host appearing in this chart is a strong signal that it requires investigation.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050] Top Risky Hosts by Open Signals

attributes.description:
**Why and when this is useful:**
This table provides the most granular view of the data used in the risk assessment. When you need to move beyond high-level trends and scores, this table gives you the specific details of each security signal. It is essential for root cause analysis and for understanding the exact nature of the risks your organization faces.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this table to investigate the alerts behind the numbers. Sort by '@timestamp' to see the latest risks. Filter by 'signal.rule.name' to focus on specific types of threats (e.g., 'Potential Ransomware Activity'). Examine the 'host.name', 'user.name', 'source.ip', and 'destination.ip' fields to understand the full context of an event. This is your primary tool for deep-dive investigation during your risk review.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050] Detailed Risk Assessment Events

attributes.description:
Why this visualization works: It provides a direct, contextualized list of the most significant anomalies related to new security signals. Instead of just seeing a spike on a chart, an analyst can immediately see the hosts, users, and source/destination IPs that are contributing most to the anomaly, accelerating the investigation process.

How an analyst can use it: Filter and sort the table by 'anomaly_score' to focus on the highest-risk events. Examine the influencer columns to identify patterns. For example, are many anomalous signals originating from a single 'source.ip' or targeting a specific 'host.name'? This information is critical for pinpointing the source of a new threat or a widespread detection issue.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050, CCI-004618] ML - Detailed New Security Signal Anomalies

attributes.description:
**Why and when this is useful:**
This trend chart helps you visualize your risk posture over time. It's essential for understanding whether your security efforts are reducing risk and for identifying when significant risk-related events occurred. It answers the question, 'Is our risk posture getting better or worse?'

**How an analyst can use it:**
Look for spikes in the chart, as they indicate a surge in security alerts and a potential security incident or widespread misconfiguration. Hover over the data points to see the exact count of signals at a specific time. Use the time selector in Kibana to zoom in on periods of high activity to correlate them with other events. The breakdown by severity helps you understand the nature of the risks being detected.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050] Risk Trend Over Time (converted)
